subject: Re: [junit] Dynamic names for tests revisited
msgSnippet: By George I think he s got it! Still, get rid of the abbreviations and use meaningful names. Since you re using Eclipse, you don t have to do much typing. :)
messageBody:
By George I think he's got it!

Still, get rid of the abbreviations and use meaningful names. Since you're using Eclipse, you don't have to do much typing. :)

BTW: if you're not using Eclipse 2.1, upgrade NOW. The refactoring tools are much nicer.

>So said Thomas Porter on 2003-06-01 --------------------
>Thanks to all for the quick responses. here is what I have so far, but
>I am still getting errors when I try to run the tests.
>
>
>The class to be tested:
>---------------------------------------------------------
>/**
> * Vol, a trivial volume object.
> *
> */
>public class Vol {
> private int hight;
> private int width;
> private int depth;
> private int volume;
>
> public Vol() {
> volume = 0;
> }
>
> /**
> * @param i
> */
> public void calcVolume(int h, int w, int d) {
> volume = h * w * d;
> }
>
> /**
> * Get the Volume value.
> * @return the Volume value.
> */
> public int getVolume() {
> return volume;
> }
>
>}
>---------------------------------------------------------
>
>The extended TestCase class: ParameterizedTestCase:
>----------------------------------------------------------
>public class ParameterizedTestCase extends TestCase {
> static int p1;
> static int p2;
> static int p3;
> static int p4;
>
> ParameterizedTestCase(int p1, int p2, int p3, int p4 ) {
> super(makeSuiteName(p1, p2, p3));
> ParameterizedTestCase.p1 = p1;
> ParameterizedTestCase.p2 = p2;
> ParameterizedTestCase.p3 = p3;
> ParameterizedTestCase.p4 = p4;
> }
> static String makeSuiteName(int p1, int p2, int p3) {
> return "ParameterizedTestCase<" + p1 + ", " + p2 + ", " + p3 + ">";
> }
>
> public void testV1() {
> Vol v1 = new Vol();
> v1.calcVolume(p1, p2, p3);
> assertEquals(p4, v1.getVolume());
> }
>
>
>}
>----------------------------------------------------------
>
>And the test code, TestVol
>---------------------------------------------------------
>mport junit.framework.Test;
>import junit.framework.TestCase;
>import junit.framework.TestSuite;
>import junit.textui.TestRunner;
>
>public class TestVol extends TestCase {
> public static Test suite() {
> TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
>
> suite.addTest(new ParameterizedTestCase(0, 0, 0, 0));
> return suite;
> }
>
>
> public static void main( String[] args ) {
> TestRunner.main( new String[] { "TestVol" } );
> }
>
>}
>---------------------------------------------------------
>
>And the error I get JUnit output captured from ant run:
>---------------------------------------------------------
>Testsuite: TestVol
>Tests run: 1, Failures: 1, Errors: 0, Time elapsed: 0.011 sec
>
>Testcase: ParameterizedTestCase<0, 0, 0> took 0.006 sec
> FAILED
>Method "ParameterizedTestCase<0, 0, 0>" not found
>junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: Method "ParameterizedTestCase<0,
>0, 0>" not found
>
>Testcase: ParameterizedTestCase<0, 0, 0>
>---------------------------------------------------------
>
>While I appear to have generated a name, which perhaps needs to change
>to a valid method name (no embedded spaces & '<' characters), it does
>not appear that the suite.addTest
>
>
>
>Yahoo! Groups Sponsor
